It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Thermoelectric power plants that draw water from natural surface water sources are only permitted to draw water from sources that meet minimum surface water flow thresholds corresponding to the amount of gallons withdrawn by the plant. The surface water flow data is used to create suitability layers corresponding to a 20km region around surface water sources that meet the corresponding MGD threshold. The source dataset was reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization.

Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 700 MGD, 20km buffer

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nhd2plus_surfaceflow_greaterthan700mgd_buffer20km.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Surface Water Flow
    Description from Source: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 9/11/16
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/30/22
    Source Data Citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Thermoelectric power plants that draw water from natural surface water sources are only permitted to draw water from sources that meet minimum surface water flow thresholds corresponding to the amount of gallons withdrawn by the plant. The surface water flow data is used to create suitability layers corresponding to a 20km region around surface water sources that meet the corresponding MGD threshold. The source dataset was reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization.

Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 70 MGD, 20km buffer

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nhd2plus_surfaceflow_greaterthan70mgd_buffer20km.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Surface Water Flow
    Description from Source: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.

    Source Data Citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).

Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 75 MGD, 20km buffer

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nhd2plus_surfaceflow_greaterthan75mgd_buffer20km.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Surface Water Flow
    Description from Source: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 95 MGD, 20km buffer

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nhd2plus_surfaceflow_greaterthan95mgd_buffer20km.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Surface Water Flow
    Description from Source: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 9/6/16
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/25/22
    Source Data Citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Thermoelectric power plants that draw water from natural surface water sources are only permitted to draw water from sources that meet minimum surface water flow thresholds corresponding to the amount of gallons withdrawn by the plant. The surface water flow data is used to create suitability layers corresponding to a 20km region around surface water sources that meet the corresponding MGD threshold. The source dataset was reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization.

National Land Cover Dataset Wetlands

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nlcd_wetlands_conus.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD) - Wetlands
    Description from Source: The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), in partnership with several federal agencies, has developed and released five National Land Cover Database (NLCD) products over the past two decades: NLCD 1992, 2001, 2006, 2011 and 2016. These products provide spatially explicit and reliable information on the Nation's land cover and land cover change. To continue the legacy of NLCD and further establish a long-term monitoring capability for the Nation's land resources, the USGS designed a new generation of NLCD products released in 2016. This design continues in 2019 and aims to provide innovative, consistent, and robust methodologies for production of a multi-temporal land cover and land cover change database from 2001 to 2019 at 2-3-year intervals. Comprehensive research was conducted and resulted in processes in streamlined processes for integrating specialized MRLC partner data along with numerous newly available dataset, assembling and preprocessing Landsat imagery and geospatial ancillary datasets; a multi-source integrated training data development and machine learning based land cover classifications; a temporally, spectrally, and spatially integrated land cover change analysis strategy; a hierarchical theme-based post-classification and integration protocol for generating land cover and change products; a continuous fields biophysical parameters modeling method; and an automated operational system for the NLCD 2019 production. These processes resulted in a five percent increase in accuracy from the 2011 product for an overall Level II & I Overall accuracy (OA) 86.4% & 90.6% in the NLCD 2016 release. (Wickham et. al, "Thematic Accuracy assessment of the NLCD 2016 land cover for the conterminous United States", Remote Sensing of Environment, volume 257, May 2021, 112357 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2021.112357 )
    Source Data Last Updated on: 6/24/21
    Source Data Accessed on: 7/18/23
    Source Data Citation: Dewitz, J. & U.S. Geological Survey. National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2019 Products (ver. 2.0, June 2021). Multi-Resoltuion Land Characteristics Consortium https://www.mrlc.gov/data/nlcd-2019-land-cover-conus (2021).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The composite GRIDCERF wetland raster uses both wetlands categories in the NLCD: Class 90 - Woody Wetlands: areas where forest or shrubland vegetation accounts for greater than 20% of vegetative cover and the soil or substrate is periodically saturated with or covered with water and Class 95 - Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands: Areas where perennial herbaceous vegetation accounts for greater than 80% of vegetative cover and the soil or substrate is periodically saturated with or covered with water. Due to the large size of the NLCD raster, we conducted the following pre-processing steps in a free and open-source GIS (QGIS; https://www.qgis.org/en/site/forusers/download.html): (1) Used the SAGA Resampling tool to aggregate the NLCD 30m data to GRIDCERF 1km resolution. We upscaled using the majority setting where the 1km gridcell would take on the majority grid cell value from the finer resoltuion data. (2) Used the Reclassify by table tool to set values for wetland classes of 90 and 95 to 1 and all other classes to 0. (3) We then used the Polygonize (raster to vector) tool to write a polygonize the 0, 1 grid cells to a shapefile. Following the pre-process steps, we reprojected the data to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system and rasterized. Any 1km grid cell that is touched by a feature geometry is burned in as part of the final raster. No additional modifications or buffers were applied.

Offshore Habitat Areas of Particular Concern

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_habitats_of_particular_concern.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Habitat Areas of Particular Concern
    Description from Source: The purpose of HAPCs is to focus conservation, management, and research efforts on subsets of EFH that are vulnerable to degradation or are especially important ecologically for federally managed fish. The HAPC designation alone does not confer additional protection or restrictions to an area, but helps to focus EFH conservation, management, and research priorities. HAPC designation is a valuable way to acknowledge areas where we have detailed information on ecological function and habitat vulnerability, indicating a greater need for conservation and management. In some instances the Councils and NMFS may develop fishery management measures to conserve the habitat within the HAPC.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 7/18/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/25/23
    Source Data Citation: NOAA, 2023: Habitat Areas of Particular Concern. National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration, https://marinecadastre-noaa.hub.arcgis.com/datasets/noaa::habitat-areas-of-particular-concern/about

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: All habitat areas are included in the GRIDCERF suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Offshore National Marine Sanctuaries

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_marine_sanctuaries.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: National Marine Sanctuary Program Digital Boundary Files
    Description from Source: The Office of National Marine Sanctuaries manages a system of sanctuaries and other managed areas around the country. The legal boundaries of these sanctuaries are defined within the Code of Federal Regulations, at 15 C.F.R. Part 922 and the subparts for each national marine sanctuary. The GIS compatible digital boundary files for each national marine sanctuary are representations of those legal boundaries and are based on the best available data. These files are available for public use at locations defined in this metadata record.
    Source Data Last Updated on: Unknown
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/22/23
    Source Data Citation: NOAA / National Marine Sanctuaries Program. National Marine Sanctuary Program Digital Boundary Files. NOAA/National Marine Sanctuaries Program, Silver Spring, Maryland. https://sanctuaries.noaa.gov/library/imast_gis.html (accessed 09/22/23).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The following marine sanctuaries are included in the composite suitability layer: Channel Islands, Cordell Bank, Florida Keys, Flower Garden Banks, Gray's Reef, Greater Farallones, Mallows Bay-Potomac River, Monitor, Monterey Bay, Olympic Coast, Stellwagen Bank, Thunder Bay, Wisconsin Shipwreck. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Offshore Danger Zones and Restricted Areas

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_offshore_danger_zones.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Danger Zones and Restricted Areas
    Description from Source: These data represent the location of Danger Zones and Restricted Areas within coastal and marine waters, as outlined by the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) and the Raster Navigational Charts (RNC). The CFR defines a Danger Zone as, "A defined water area (or areas) used for target practice, bombing, rocket firing or other especially hazardous operations, normally for the armed forces. The danger zones may be closed to the public on a full-time or intermittent basis, as stated in the regulations." The CFR defines a Restricted Area as, "A defined water area for the purpose of prohibiting or limiting public access to the area. Restricted areas generally provide security for Government property and/or protection to the public from the risks of damage or injury arising from the Government's use of that area." Other features in this dataset include: Danger Area, Missile Testing Area, Naval Operations Area, Prohibited Area, Restricted Airspace, Test Area, and Torpedo Testing Area. Authoritative information relating to these data may be found in Title 33, Chapter II of the CFR (Part 334).
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/20/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/22/23
    Source Data Citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023. Danger Zones and Restricted Areas. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/48876.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: All areas in the dataset are included in the compiled suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Offshore Munitions and Explosives of Concern

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_offshore_munitions_zones.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Munitions and Explosives of Concern
    Description from Source: Munitions and explosives of concern (MEC) have been deposited on the seabed of the United States Outer Continental Shelf since World War I. The bulk of these munitions have originated from the U.S. Armed Forces while conducting military training exercises, war-time placement, and disposal and dumping activities. Since 1972, ocean disposal of munitions and other pollutants has been banned by the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. Federal and state efforts to mitigate, map, monitor, and sometimes remove these munitions are ongoing. The term MEC defines a collection of munitions including a) unexploded ordnance, b) discarded military munitions, and c) munition constituents that are present in high enough concentrations to pose an explosive hazard.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 6/7/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/22/23
    Source Data Citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Munitions and Explosives of Concern NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/69013.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: All areas in the dataset are included in the compiled suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Offshore Wrecks and Obstructions

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_offshore_wrecks_obstructions.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wrecks and Obstructions
    Description from Source: Shipwrecks and obstructions in the ocean have long been a hazard to navigation and construction, and points of interest to archaeologists, recreational divers, fishermen, educators, and explorers. Locating hazardous wrecks and obstructions is part of the ongoing NOAA charting process. The exact position of many wrecks is difficult to determine because of changes in the environment, varied survey methods, and human error. Some wrecks are intentionally placed in the ocean to serve as artificial reefs or for disposal. Others pose a health and environmental threat from their cargo. Ownership and control over wrecks and obstructions is governed by a collection of state and federal regulations, the Abandoned Shipwreck Act, National Historic Preservation Act, and National Marine Sanctuaries Act.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 8/10/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/25/23
    Source Data Citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Wrecks and Obstructions. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/70439.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: All areas in the dataset are included in the compiled suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Weather Radar Stations, 5 Mile Buffer

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_radar_stations_5mi_buffer.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Weather Radar Stations
    Description from Source: These data represent Next-Generation Radar (NEXRAD) and Terminal Doppler Weather Radar (TDWR) weather radar stations within the US. The NEXRAD radar stations are maintained and operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The TDWR radar stations are maintained and operated by the Federal Aviation Administration.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/1/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/25/23
    Source Data Citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Weather Radar Stations, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/48940 (accessed 09/25/23).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Weather radar points included in the source data + a buffer of 5 miles are considered unsuitable areas. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Offshore Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_shipping_lanes_regulations_buffer_3km.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones for US waters
    Description from Source: The automatic identification system (AIS) is a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to add value and make available some of the most important historical records from the U.S. Coast Guard's national network of AIS receivers. This data set represents annual vessel transit counts summarized at a 100-meter by 100-meter geographic area. A single transit is counted each time a vessel track passes through, starts, or stops within a 100-meter grid cell.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/30/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/25/23
    Source Data Citation: Office of Coast Survey, 2023: Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones for US waters. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/39986.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The GRIDCERF suitability layer excludes the following areas in the dataset: Shipping Fairways Lanes and Zones, Traffic Separation Schemes, Traffic Separateion Schemes/Traffic Lanes, and Recommended Routes. A 3 km buffer is applied to the composite areas. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Offshore Submarine Cable Areas

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_noaa_submarine_cable_areas.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Submarine Cable Areas
    Description from Source: These data show the general location of commercial and research submarine cables within U.S. waters. The majority of these cables are for telecommunications, and the remaining are for power transmission. The geographic footprint for each cable may vary and is dependent on the original source data. In the near shore, cables are routinely buried below the seabed. Offshore, they are placed directly on the seabed. A submarine cable area may contain one or more physical cables, and 30 CFR 585.301 defines a minimum 100-foot-wide right of way grant on each side of a cable.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/1/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/25/23
    Source Data Citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Submarine Cable Areas. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/66190.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: All submarine cable areas are included in the composite raster. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

US National Park Service Tract and Boundary Area

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nps_administrative_boundaries_conus.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: National Park Service tract and boundary
    Description from Source: This service depicts National Park Service tract and boundary data that was created by the Land Resources Division. NPS Director's Order #25 states: "Land status maps will be prepared to identify the ownership of the lands within the authorized boundaries of the park unit. These maps, showing ownership and acreage, are the 'official record' of the acreage of Federal and non-federal lands within the park boundaries. While these maps are the official record of the lands and acreage within the unit's authorized boundaries, they are not of survey quality and not intended to be used for survey purposes." As such this data is intended for use as a tool for GIS analysis. It is in no way intended for engineering or legal purposes. The data accuracy is checked against best available sources which may be dated and vary by location. NPS assumes no liability for use of this data. The boundary polygons represent the current legislated boundary of a given NPS unit. NPS does not necessarily have full fee ownership or hold another interest (easement, right of way, etc...) in all parcels contained within this boundary. Equivalently NPS may own or have an interest in parcels outside the legislated boundary of a given unit. In order to obtain complete information about current NPS interests both inside and outside a unit's legislated boundary tract level polygons are also created by NPS Land Resources Division and should be used in conjunction with this boundary data. To download this data directly from the NPS go to https://irma.nps.gov/App/Portal/Home Property ownership data is compiled from deeds, plats, surveys, and other source data. These are not engineering quality drawings and should be used for administrative purposes only. The National Park Service (NPS) shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such. The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. The related graphics are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use the related graphics as data. The National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an NPS server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the National Park Service, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 7/6/23
    Source Data Accessed on: 7/18/23
    Source Data Citation: National Park Service. National Park Service Boundary. National Park Service https://public-nps.opendata.arcgis.com/datasets/nps::nps-boundary-4/about (2023).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system and rasterized. Any 1km grid cell that is touched by a feature geometry is burned in as part of the final raster. No additional modifications or buffers are applied.

US National Park Service National Historic Trails

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nps_historic_trails_conus.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: National Historic Trails
    Description from Source: National Historic Trails in the United States. The data used to create this map is a representation of the trails and in many cases an approximation and may not represent the exact location of the trails. National Historic Trails shown represent Congressionally-designated routes associated with historic trails; they are not fully developed hiking trails and may not represent physical trails. Always consult the official source for the most up-to-date information.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 9/5/19
    Source Data Accessed on: 7/18/23
    Source Data Citation: National Park Service. National Historic Trails. Geospatial Energy Mapper https://gem.anl.gov/tool (2019).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system. A 1000 meter buffer is added to the linestring geometry prior to rasterization. Any 1km grid cell that is touched by a feature geometry is burned in as part of the final raster.

US National Park Service National Scenic Trails

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nps_scenic_trails_conus.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: National Scenic Trails
    Description from Source: National Scenic Trails in the United States. The data used to create this map is a representation of the trails and in many cases an approximation and may not represent the exact location of the trails. National Scenic Trials shown represent physical hiking trails, however many sections may still be in the design or planning stage and not yet complete. Always consult the official source for the most up-to-date information.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 9/19/19
    Source Data Accessed on: 7/18/23
    Source Data Citation: National Park Service. National Scenic Trails. Geospatial Energy Mapper https://gem.anl.gov/tool (2019).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system. A 1000 meter buffer is added to the linestring geometry prior to rasterization. Any 1km grid cell that is touched by a feature geometry is burned in as part of the final raster.

EGS Geothermal No Resource Potential

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_geothermal_no_resource_potential.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: U.S. Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS)
    Description from Source: This dataset shows the relative favorability of deep Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) in the contiguous United States based on levelized cost of electricity estimated from adequate temperature and depth combinations.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2/22/18
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/10/23
    Source Data Citation: NREL, 2018. U.S. Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS). National Renewable Energy Laboratory. https://www.nrel.gov/gis/assets/data/egs.zip (accessed 10/10/23)

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The class level of the geothermal resource indicates favorability where 1 is the most favorable and 5 is the least favorable for deep enhanced geothermal capability based on temperature and depth combinations. For the GRIDCERF geothermal potential layer, a suitability rasters is built for the indicated resource class, where areas not meeting at least that resource class are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_geothermal_potential_class1_or_greater.tif

    Description from Source: This dataset shows the relative favorability of deep Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) in the contiguous United States based on levelized cost of electricity estimated from adequate temperature and depth combinations.

Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) Potential, 20% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_solar_csp_potential_20cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Concentrating Solar Direct Normal Potential
    Description from Source: Monthly and annual average direct normal irradiance for Hawaii and the contiguous United States
    Source Data Last Updated on: 8/29/16
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/14/22
    Source Data Citation: Perez, R. et al. A new operational model for satellite-derived irradiances: description and validation. Solar Energy 73, 307-317 (2002).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The suitability layers for Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) potential correspond to areas capable of meeting a specified capacity factor on an annual average basis. Areas with suitable direct normal irradiance levels to meet the capacity factor are considered suitable. It is assumed that CSP plants are paired with energy storage which meets half of their required capacity factor. The required irradiance level corresponds to the (.5 * AC CapacityFactor * 24). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Potential, 10% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_solar_pv_potential_10cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Photovoltaic Potential
    Description from Source: Monthly and annual average global horizontal irradiance for Hawaii and the contiguous United States.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 8/29/16
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/14/22
    Source Data Citation: Perez, R. et al. A new operational model for satellite-derived irradiances: description and validation. Solar Energy 73, 307-317 (2002).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The suitability layers for solar photovoltaic potential correspond to areas capable of meeting a specified capacity factor on an annual average basis. Areas with suitable global horizontal irradiance levels to meet the capacity factor are considered suitable. The required irradiance level corresponds to the (DC CapacityFactor * 24)/(InverterEfficiency * Derate). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Potential, 12% Capacity Factor or Greater

The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Potential, 16% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_solar_pv_potential_16cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Photovoltaic Potential
    Description from Source: Monthly and annual average global horizontal irradiance for Hawaii and the contiguous United States.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 8/29/16
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/14/22
    Source Data Citation: Perez, R. et al. A new operational model for satellite-derived irradiances: description and validation. Solar Energy 73, 307-317 (2002).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The suitability layers for solar photovoltaic potential correspond to areas capable of meeting a specified capacity factor on an annual average basis. Areas with suitable global horizontal irradiance levels to meet the capacity factor are considered suitable. The required irradiance level corresponds to the (DC CapacityFactor * 24)/(InverterEfficiency * Derate). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Potential, 18% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_solar_pv_potential_18cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Photovoltaic Potential
    Description from Source: Monthly and annual average global horizontal irradiance for Hawaii and the contiguous United States.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 8/29/16
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/14/22
    Source Data Citation: Perez, R. et al. A new operational model for satellite-derived irradiances: description and validation. Solar Energy 73, 307-317 (2002).

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The suitability layers for solar photovoltaic potential correspond to areas capable of meeting a specified capacity factor on an annual average basis. Areas with suitable global horizontal irradiance levels to meet the capacity factor are considered suitable. The required irradiance level corresponds to the (DC CapacityFactor * 24)/(InverterEfficiency * Derate). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

    Source Data Title: Photovoltaic Potential

The required irradiance level corresponds to the (DC CapacityFactor * 24)/(InverterEfficiency * Derate). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Onshore Wind 100m Hub Height Resource Potential, 25% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_wind_offshore_potential_100m_25cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/15/15
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).

Source Data 2:
    Source Data Title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Onshore Wind 100m Hub Height Resource Potential, 30% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_wind_offshore_potential_100m_30cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.

    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States.     Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Onshore Wind 140m Hub Height Resource Potential, 35% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_wind_offshore_potential_140m_35cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/15/15
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).

Source Data 2:
    Source Data Title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Onshore Wind 160m Hub Height Resource Potential, 55% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_wind_offshore_potential_160m_55cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/15/15
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).

Source Data 2:
    Source Data Title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/15/15
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).

Source Data 2:
    Source Data Title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Onshore Wind 140m Hub Height Resource Potential, 15% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_wind_onshore_potential_140m_15cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/15/15
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).

Source Data 2:
    Source Data Title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

    Source Data Title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
    Description from Source: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Onshore Wind 80m Hub Height Resource Potential, 20% Capacity Factor or Greater

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_nrel_wind_onshore_potential_80m_2cf.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
    Description from Source: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/15/15
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).

    Source Data Last Updated on: 2012
    Source Data Accessed on: 10/3/23
    Source Data Citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. Offshore Outer Continental Shelf Areas Withdrawn from Leasing

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_offshore_areas_withdrawn_from_leasing.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Outer Continental Shelf Areas Withdrawn from Leasing
    Description from Source: These data represent areas that are permanently or temporarily withdrawn from oil, gas, renewable, critical mineral, or sand leasing or some combination of these by various authorities, including the Gulf of Mexico Security Act of 2006, presidential withdrawals under Sec. 12 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, 43 U.S.C. Sec. 1341, or the National Marine Sanctuaries Act, 16 U.S.C. Sec. 1431-1434, 33 U.S.C. 1401 et seq. Additionally, some marine national monuments within the area under BOEM's leasing authority include language that restricts certain types of leases.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 1/4/21
    Source Data Accessed on: 9/25/23
    Source Data Citation: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management - Office of Strategic Resouces, 2021: BOEM Outer Continental Shelf Areas Withdrawn from Leasing. Departement of Interior - Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, https://www.boem.gov/oil-gas-energy/leasing/boemocsareas-withdrawn-leasing-2021.zip

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: For the GRIDCERF suitability layer, only excluded areas that are applicable to renewable energy development ('ORSM', 'ORM') and those that are permanently excluded are added to the exclusion area used. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

Densely Populated Areas, SSP2 2020

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2020_1km_conus_50k_per25sqmi.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756179

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle and all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within that circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people.

Densely Populated Areas with 25 mile buffer, SSP2 2020

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2020_1km_conus_50k_per25sqmi_25buffer.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756230

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle, all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within the circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

Densely Populated Areas - nuclear specific SSP2 2020

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2020_1km_conus_nuclear.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756281

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

Densely Populated Areas, SSP2 2025

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2025_1km_conus_50k_per25sqmi.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.

Any 25-square mile circle and all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within that circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people.

Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

Any 25-square mile circle and all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within that circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people.

Densely Populated Areas with 25 mile buffer, SSP2 2030

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2030_1km_conus_50k_per25sqmi_25buffer.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756232

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle, all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within the circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

Densely Populated Areas - nuclear specific SSP2 2030

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2030_1km_conus_nuclear.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756283

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2070_1km_conus_50k_per25sqmi_25buffer.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756240

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle, all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within the circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

Densely Populated Areas - nuclear specific SSP2 2070

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp2_2070_1km_conus_nuclear.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756291

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756248

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle, all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within the circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

Densely Populated Areas - nuclear specific SSP3 2025

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp3_2025_1km_conus_nuclear.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756299

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756256

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle, all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within the circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

Densely Populated Areas - nuclear specific SSP3 2065

GRIDCERF Layer Name: gridcerf_population_ssp3_2065_1km_conus_nuclear.tif

Source Data 1:
    Source Data Title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Description from Source: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
    Source Data Last Updated on: 5/17/20
    Source Data Accessed on: 11/3/21
    Source Data Citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756307

GRIDCERF Composite Data Layer Methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.
